1-9-3: BUILDING DEPARTMENT:
1-9-3-1: CREATION; MEMBERS, COMPENSATION:
   A.   Creation: There is hereby created a building department of the village
which shall consist of a Director of Community and Economic Development,
building commissioner, an electrical inspector, a plumbing inspector, a code
enforcement officer and any other inspectors as the board of trustees may from
time to time prescribe. The building department shall also be known as the
community development department and those terms may be used interchangeably in
this code.
   B.   Inspectors’ Appointments: The electrical inspector, plumbing inspector,
code enforcement officer and any other inspectors which the board of trustees
may deem necessary shall be hired, and may be replaced by the village
administrator. In addition, the board of trustees may enter into contracts with
third party entities for such entities to provide code enforcement services on
behalf of the village through nonvillage employees when such practice is
recommended by the village administrator.
   C.   Compensation: The Director of Community and Economic Development,
building commissioner, code enforcement officer and other inspectors shall
receive such compensation as may be provided from time to time by ordinance or
resolution of the board of trustees.
(Ord. 2015-46, 10-13-2015; amd. Ord. 2025-16, 5-13-2025)
1-9-3-2: POWERS AND DUTIES OF DEPARTMENTS:
   A.   Stop Work Orders: The building commissioner, code enforcement officer
or inspectors or employees of third party entities with which the village has a
contract for code enforcement services shall have the power to order all work
stopped on buildings or structures in the course of construction, alteration or
repair, when such work is being done in violation of any provision of any
ordinance relating thereto or in violation of the zoning ordinance 1 . Such
work shall not be resumed after the issuance of such stop order until all
violations have been corrected. If the stop work order is oral, it shall be
followed by a written stop order within one hour, or as soon thereafter as
possible. Such written stop order may be served by the building commissioner,
code enforcement officer or any police officer of the village, or any employee
of such third party entity with which the village has a contract for code
enforcement services.
   B.   Violation Complaints: The building department, concurrently with the
police department, shall have the duties of inspection, notification, issuance
of nontraffic complaints and other aspects of the prosecution of violators of
titles 4, 5 and 6 of this code. The building commissioner, code enforcement
officer or a building inspector or an employee of a third party entity with
which the village has a contract for code enforcement services or a member of
the police department may issue such nontraffic complaints as are necessary to
enforce this subsection. (Ord. 2015-46, 10-13-2015)
 
Notes
1 1. See section 9-1-1 of the village zoning ordinance.
1-9-3-3: BUILDING COMMISSIONER/COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT DIRECTOR:
   A.   Appointment: The building commissioner shall be appointed by the
president by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees.
   B.   Powers And Duties:
      1.   It shall be his duty to see to the enforcement of the provisions of
all codes and ordinances relating to building.
      2.   He will oversee all permitting processes and code compliance
activities in the village.
      3.   He shall work with outside agencies such as the federal emergency
management agency (FEMA) on flood issues and remediation; the Illinois
environmental protection agency (IEPA) on all environmental codes and practices
including the national pollutant discharge elimination system (NPDES) and with
Lake County stormwater management commission (LCSMC) on all drainage and
wetland requirements and enforcement.
      4.   He shall inspect all buildings or structures being erected or
altered as frequently as may be necessary to ensure compliance with the village
ordinances, and shall supervise the activities of all staff members in the
department including the electrical inspector, plumbing inspector, code
enforcement officer or any other inspectors appointed to his department.
      5.   The building commissioner shall have the power to enter at any
reasonable hour into any building or premises where the work of altering,
repairing or construction of any building or structure is going on, for the
purpose of making inspections.
      6.   The building commissioner shall have the power to issue business
licenses and occupancy permits. There shall be no occupancy upon the building
until an occupancy permit has been issued.
      7.   He shall perform such other duties as may be required by the village
board, not inconsistent with this section, and he shall report directly to the
Director of Community and Economic Development.
   C.   Annual Inspection Of Commercial And Industrial Buildings: The building
department shall make an annual inspection of all commercial and industrial
buildings in the village, unless in that year an inspection is made by the
building department as a condition of issuing a business license, in which
event the inspection made as a condition of issuing a business license shall
constitute that year's annual inspection. The inspection to be made pursuant to
this subsection shall be based on the terms and provisions of the international
property maintenance code, as adopted by the village and as amended from time
to time, including the various codes incorporated by reference in the
international property maintenance code. Nothing herein stated shall be
interpreted or construed as precluding the building department from making any
other inspection that said building department may determine appropriate. In
the event the inspection results in a satisfactory condition, a certificate of
occupancy for that year shall issue from the building department. The cost of
any such inspection shall be determined from the following schedule: (Ord. 99-
09, 3-1-1999; amd. Ord. 2000-05, 3-20-2000; Ord. 2008-18, 5-13-2008)
 
Area Of Inspection           Inspection Fee
1 - 1,000 square feet        $ 25.00
1,001 - 20,000 square feet   50.00
20,001 - 100,000 square feet 75.00
100,001 and above            100.00
 
   In the event a second inspection is made, the inspection fee shall be twenty
five dollars ($25.00). In the event a third inspection is made, the inspection
fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). (Ord. 99-09, 3-1-1999; amd. Ord. 2000-05,
3-20-2000)
   D.   Facade Improvement Program: The objective of the program is to
encourage exterior improvements that preserve and enhance the character of the
village consistent with the concepts identified in the village comprehensive
plan, downtown and lakefront vision plan, and Fox Lake Station area plan (RTA).
The general intent of this section is that owners of approved commercial
property on which a business is being operated who install at least one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00) of improvements to the facades and storefronts are
eligible to receive a grant equal to fifty percent (50%) of the cost of the
work, up to a maximum grant of four thousand dollars ($4,000.00) per address
per fiscal year. Individual applicants who own multiple storefronts may apply
for more than one grant in a given fiscal year, but no more than one grant per
address may be applied for in any fiscal year.
      1.   Eligible Improvements: Improvements which may be eligible for grants
under the facade improvement program are as follows:
         a.   Signage.
         b.   Awnings/canopies/shutters.
         c.   Brick cleaning.
         d.   Tuck pointing.
         e.   Landscaping elements including fixed planters.
         f.   Repair or replacement of windows and/or doors.
         g.   Display window upgrades.
         h.   Permanent exterior decorative lighting.
         i.   Repair or replacement of siding or masonry.
         j.   Painting.
         k.   Restoration of original architectural features.
      2.   Ineligible Improvements: Improvements which are ineligible for
grants under the facade improvement program are as follows:
         a.   Routine maintenance of building such as roof replacement or
repaving an existing parking lot.
         b.   Interior improvements to a building, unless a display window
upgrade.
         c.   Disposal or cleanup costs.
         d.   Code violation corrections.
         e.   New construction.
         f.   Purchase of furnishings, equipment or other personal property
which does not become part of the real estate.
         g.   Improvements completed or expenses incurred prior to notification
of approval.
         h.   Architectural and engineering fees.
      3.   Criteria For Grant Eligibility: The criteria used to determine
eligibility for grants under the facade improvement program are as follows:
         a.   The compatibility of the proposed improvements with the overall
architectural design goals for the area;
         b.   Compliance with the village building codes, zoning codes and sign
regulations, and the comprehensive plan;
         c.   The relationship between the proposed improvements and the
general character of the streetscape and other buildings in the area;
         d.   The overall impact of the improvements on the appearance and
marketability of the building;
         e.   The relationship between the improvements and the original
architecture of historic significance of the building or area;
         f.   Grants will be limited to buildings in the facade improvement
district.
      4.   Procedure: Forms for grant applications shall be available at the
community development department. The procedure for evaluation of applications
shall be as follows:
         a.   Completed application packet shall be filed with the community
development department. Applications shall not be deemed to be complete unless
all required documentation is provided, including, but not limited to, a
preliminary design sketch, a description of needed work items and three (3)
third party estimates of the cost of the anticipated work. In addition the
applicant should indicate which bid they are approving and provide the signed
executed agreements. If work to be completed by owner, paid receipts needed for
materials only.
         b.   After receipt of completed application, the Director of Community
and Economic Development shall meet with the applicant to review the
application. At the conclusion of said meeting (or continued meeting date if
the application is deemed incomplete), the Director of Community and Economic
Development shall determine whether the application is eligible for a grant.
The application may be amended on its face to meet concerns or suggestions of
the Director of Community and Economic Development. The decision shall be
submitted in writing to the applicant and to the president and board of
trustees at the next regularly scheduled village board meeting.
         c.   If the Director of Community and Economic Development finds the
applicant to be ineligible for a grant and the applicant notifies the Director
of Community and Economic Development that the applicant desires to appeal the
decision of ineligibility within seven (7) days after the decision in writing
is issued, then copies of the application shall be furnished by the Director of
Community and Economic Development to the village board and the village board
shall consider the application at its next meeting on which the application can
be placed on the agenda and shall either vote to find the application eligible,
find the application ineligible, or request further information from either the
applicant or Director of Community and Economic Development. If further
information is provided, the village board shall vote promptly thereafter, and
the decision of the village board shall be final. Nothing herein shall prevent
the applicant from withdrawing the application prior to a decision by the
village board.
         d.   Application for reimbursement shall be submitted along with
completed W-9, proof of payment, invoices, and lien waivers to the community
development department. Neither the community development department nor the
village shall have any liability to any party for review or evaluation of any
such documents.
         e.   Applicant is responsible for obtaining such building permits as
are necessary for any improvements.
         f.   Any changes to approved plans or drawings must be approved by the
Director of Community and Economic Development prior to being made. The amount
of the approved grant shall not be increased without village board approval.
         g.   Upon approval by the village board, the applicant may proceed
with the project in accordance with the procedures established by the village
codes.
         h.   All work for which an application is approved shall be completed
within six (6) months after approval by the village board of the application.
Extension of three (3) months may be granted by village board approval only.
The community development department will send notice thirty (30) days prior to
the grant application expiration indicating that time is about to run out and
the petitioner needs to contact the community development department if they
wish to ask the village board for an extension. Should the petitioner not apply
within a thirty (30) day period after the six (6) month expiration, the grant
will be forfeited back to the village. Following completion of the work, the
village community development department will inspect the work for conformance
with the approved plans and drawings and compliance with village codes. Any
business found to be in violation of any village code or ordinance or be in
arrears of any payments or having outstanding debt to the village shall not be
eligible for participation in this program until all violations are corrected
and payments made. If a business applies for and is awarded a grant and at a
later date declines the funding, the owner must do so in writing so that the
village has a record of the refusal of funds.
         i.   Any and all applications for payment shall be submitted to the
village within one hundred twenty (120) days after completion of the work. No
amounts shall be approved for payment in excess of the village’s portion of the
preliminary cost estimate submitted with the application, and no check shall be
issued by the village unless the applicant and contractor have acknowledged in
writing that the work is complete, applicant has paid applicant’s portion of
the cost of the work, and final waivers of lien are delivered to the village
for all labor and materials supplied to complete the work. If a payment
application is not made within that time, or if the work is not completed
within six (6) months after village board approval of the application, then the
village will not make payment for the improvements for which the application
was previously approved.
      5.   Funding: Each fiscal year the village shall appropriate or budget
such funds as are deemed appropriate for providing grants described herein.
Only such funds as have been appropriated or budgeted shall be disbursed. When
grant applications have been approved totaling the approximate appropriated or
budgeted amount for any fiscal period, then additional applications shall be
accepted but shall not be acted upon until the beginning of the next fiscal
year. Also, any applications which have not been approved at the time the
budgeted amount has been achieved may proceed through the approval process but
the applicant shall be notified that funding may not occur until the following
fiscal period. Any applications which have been approved but so deferred shall
be at the top of the list for funding in the next fiscal period.
      6.   Definitions: The following words and terms shall have the following
meanings for purposes of the interpretations of this section:
         BUSINESS DISTRICT: All property zoned as B-2, B-3, B-4, B-5 and D in
the village limits of the village of Fox Lake.
         FACADE: The front or main face of a building or other exterior walls
which are visible from a public street or waterway.
         FACADE IMPROVEMENT DISTRICT: Properties zoned as B-2, B-3, B-4, B-5,
D, M-1, M-2 and PUDs with underlying B-2, B-3, B-4, B-5, D, M-1 and M-2 zoning
within the territorial limits of the village shall be eligible for the facade
improvement program.
         STOREFRONT: That portion of a building facade which provides direct
access and visibility to a separate business establishment at the street level.
The term storefront shall also include all signs, awnings, and window display
areas associated with the business establishment.
(Ord. 2014-34, 11-25-2014; amd. Ord. 2017-13, 3-14-2017; Ord. 2025-16, 5-13-
2025)
1-9-3-4: CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER, DUTIES:
   The primary function of the code enforcement officer and employees of third
party entities with which the village has a contract for code enforcement
services shall be to assist in the prosecution of violations of titles 4, 5 and
6 of this code by conducting the necessary investigation, notification and
follow up. Such persons shall work in cooperation with the police department
and community development department and shall report their activities to the
Director of Community and Economic Development.
(Ord. 2015-46, 10-13-2015; amd. Ord. 2025-16, 5-13-2025)
1-9-4: DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS:
1-9-4-1: CREATION; MEMBERS:
   A.   Creation: There is hereby created a department of public works of the
village which shall consist of a superintendent of public works and such other
members as the board of trustees may from time to time prescribe. The
department of public works shall be in charge of the local sewer and water
systems of the village and may also be referred to as the local sewer and water
department. The supervisor of the local sewer and water department shall serve
as acting superintendent of public works in the absence of the appointment of a
separate superintendent of public works.
   B.   Appointments: The members of the department of public works and local
sewer and water department shall be appointed or employed as follows:
      1.   The superintendent shall take applications of prospective
applicants, shall interview them and make an investigation of applicants which
he shall deem expedient.
      2.   The superintendent shall notify the village administrator of his or
her recommendations, and the village administrator shall review the
recommendations and hire the applicant deemed appropriate by the village
administrator and notify the president and board of trustees of such hiring.
(Ord. 2015-29, 5-26-2015)
1-9-4-2: DEPARTMENT DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the members of the department of public works to
perform any duties delegated to them by the superintendent of public works.
(1975 Code § 3.10)
1-9-4-3: SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC WORKS:
The superintendent of public works and the supervisor of the local sewer and
water department shall be employed by the village administrator. The
superintendent of public works shall be in charge of the sewer and water
department, and all members thereof shall be subject to his order. He may make
rules for the functioning of the department of public works, subject to the
approval of the board of trustees. He shall keep such records and make such
reports of the activities of the department as may be required by statute or
ordinance. The compensation of the superintendent of public works and
supervisor of the local sewer and water department, and members of the
departments shall be established by the village president and board of
trustees. (Ord. 2015-29, 5-26-2015)
1-9-5: STREET DEPARTMENT:
1-9-5-1: CREATION; MEMBERS:
   A.   Created: There is hereby created the street department of the village
which shall consist of a supervisor of streets and such other members as the
board may from time to time prescribe.
   B.   Appointments: The members of the street department shall be appointed
or employed as follows:
      1.   The supervisor shall take applications of prospective applicants,
shall interview them, and make any further investigation of applicants which he
may deem expedient.
      2.   The supervisor shall notify the village administrator of his or her
recommendations, and the village administrator shall review the recommendations
and hire the applicant deemed appropriate by the village administrator and
notify the president and board of trustees of such hiring. (Ord. 2015-29, 5-26-
2015)
1-9-5-2: DEPARTMENT DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the members of the street department to perform any
duties delegated to them by the supervisor of the street department. (Ord.
2015-29, 5-26-2015)
1-9-5-3: SUPERVISOR OF STREETS:
The supervisor of streets shall be employed by the village administrator. The
supervisor of streets shall be in charge of the street department, and all
members thereof shall be subject to his orders. He may make rules for the
functioning of the street department, subject to the approval of the board of
trustees. He shall keep such records and make such reports of the activities of
the department as may be required by statute or ordinance. The compensation of
the supervisor and members of the department shall be established by the
president and board of trustees. (Ord. 2015-29, 5-26-2015)
1-9-6: PARKS AND RECREATION DEPARTMENT:
1-9-6-1: CREATION; MEMBERS:
   A.   Created: The Parks and Recreation Department of the Village which shall
consist of a Director of Parks and Recreation and such other members as the
Board of Trustees may from time to time prescribe. (Ord. 2008-08, 2-22-2000)
1-9-6-2: DIRECTOR OF PARKS AND RECREATION:
The Director of Parks and Recreation shall be appointed by the Village
President by and with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. The
Director of Parks and Recreation shall be in charge of the Parks and Recreation
Department, and all members thereof shall be subject to his or her orders. He
or she may make rules for the functioning of the Parks and Recreation
Department, subject to the approval of the Board of Trustees. He or she shall
keep such records and make such reports of the activities of the department as
may be required by statute or ordinance. The compensation of the Director and
members of the department shall be established by the President and the Board
of Trustees. (Ord. 2000-08, 2-22-2000; amd. Ord. 2017-23, 5-9-2017)
CHAPTER 10
FINANCES
SECTION:
1-10-1: Audit
1-10-2: Appropriations
1-10-3: Tax Levy
1-10-4: Budget
1-10-5: Bills; Payroll
1-10-6: Surety Bonds
1-10-7: Municipal Purchasing
1-10-7-1: Purchasing Policy
1-10-7-2: Purchases Over Twenty Thousand Dollars
1-10-7-3: Bidding Procedure
1-10-7-4: Conflicts
1-10-7-5: Investment Policy
1-10-1: AUDIT 1 :
   A.   As soon as practicable at the close of each fiscal year, and not later
than six (6) months thereafter, there shall be an audit of all accounts of the
Village, made by a competent person authorized to act as an auditor under the
laws of Illinois, to be designated by the Board. Copies of such audit report
shall be filed with the Clerk and any other officers, departments or places as
may be required by law.
   B.   The Village Board of Trustees shall not employ the same Village Auditor
for longer than six (6) years. After six (6) years of service by the same
Village Auditor, a six (6) year interval of time shall pass before the same
auditor is employed again by the Village. (Ord. 99-21, 6-7-1999)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/8-8-1 et seq.
1-10-2: APPROPRIATIONS:
During the first quarter of each fiscal year, the Board may enact an
appropriation ordinance in which shall be itemized all anticipated expenditures
for the coming year, other than those payable from bond issues. Such ordinance
shall be published within ten (10) days after its enactment. No indebtedness
shall be incurred, excepting such indebtedness as may be payable solely from
the proceeds of a duly authorized bond issue or from a designated specified
source, unless there is a prior appropriation; provided, that during the first
quarter of any fiscal year, before the enactment of the current appropriation
ordinance, the Village may operate under the appropriation of the preceding
year. This section shall be in effect for the fiscal year ending April 30,
2015, after which the Village shall operate under the budget system set forth
in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-2-9.1 through 9.10, as said statutes may
be amended from time to time. (Ord. 2014-36, 11-25-2014)
1-10-3: TAX LEVY:
Not sooner than ten (10) days after the publication of the appropriation
ordinance for fiscal years ending prior to May 1, 2015, and the annual budget
ordinance for all fiscal years beginning with May 1, 2015, a tax levy ordinance
shall be enacted levying such taxes as may be needed to meet the anticipated
expenses of the coming year, together with such taxes as may be required to
meet outstanding bond issues, or for purposes payable from special taxes
properly authorized. A certified copy of the tax levy ordinance shall be filed
with the County Clerk of both Lake and McHenry Counties not later than the last
Tuesday in December of each year. Such ordinance shall show the total
appropriated or budgeted for each item, and the amount of tax levied therefor.
(Ord. 2014-36, 11-25-2014)
1-10-4: BUDGET:
   A.   Compilation And Contents Of Budget: The budget officer shall compile a
budget which contains estimates of revenues available to the Village for the
fiscal year for which the budget is drafted, together with recommended
expenditures for the Village and all of its departments, commissions, and
boards. Revenue estimates and expenditure recommendations shall be presented in
a manner which is in conformity with good fiscal management practices.
Substantial conformity to a chart of accounts recommended by the National
Committee on Governmental Accounting, the Auditor of Public Accounts of the
State of Illinois, or the Division of Local Government Affairs and Property
Taxes of the Department of Revenue of the State of Illinois or successor
agencies thereof shall be deemed proof of such conformity. The budget shall
contain actual or estimated revenues and expenditures for the two (2) years
immediately preceding the fiscal year for which the budget is prepared. So far
as is possible, the fiscal data for such two (2) preceding fiscal years shall
be itemized in the manner which is in conformity with the chart of accounts
recommended above. Each budget shall show the specific fund from which each
anticipated expenditure shall be made.
   B.   Passage Of Annual Budget; Effect:
      1.   Passage of the annual budget by adoption of an appropriate ordinance
by the Corporate Authorities shall be in lieu of passage of the appropriation
ordinance as required by 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-2-9.
      2.   The annual budget shall be published in the manner provided for in
subsection F of this section.
      3.   The annual budget shall be adopted by the Corporate Authorities
before the beginning of the fiscal year to which it applies.
   C.   Capital Improvement, Repair Or Replacement Fund:
      1.   In the preparation of the budget by the budget officer, an amount
not to exceed three percent (3%) of the equalized assessed value of property
subject to taxation by the Village may be accumulated in a separate fund for
the purpose or purposes of specific capital improvements, repairs, and/or
replacement of specific types of Municipal equipment or other tangible
property, both real and personal, to be designated as the "Capital Improvement,
Repair or Replacement Fund".
      2.   Expenditures from the Capital Improvement, Repair or Replacement
Fund shall be budgeted in the fiscal year in which the capital improvement,
repair or replacement will occur.
      3.   Upon the completion or abandonment of any project, or in the event
any surplus monies remain after the completion or abandonment of any project
for which the Capital Improvement, Repair or Replacement Fund was instituted,
then such funds no longer necessary for capital improvement, repair or
replacement shall be transferred to the General Corporate Fund of the Village
on the first day of the fiscal year following such abandonment or completion,
or discovery of surplus funds.
   D.   Revision Of Annual Budget:
      1.   The Village Board may delegate authority to heads of Village
departments, boards or commissions, to delete, add to, change or create
subclasses within object classes budgeted previously to the department, board,
or commission, subject to such limitation or requirement for prior approval by
the budget officer, as the Village Board, upon a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the
Corporate Authorities then holding office, may establish.
      2.   By a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the members of the Corporate
Authorities then holding office, the annual budget for the Village may be
revised by deleting, adding to, changing, or creating subclasses within object
classes and object classes themselves.
      3.   No revision of the budget shall be made increasing the total budget
in the event funds are not available to effectuate the purpose of the revision.
   E.   Funds For Contingency Purposes: The annual budget may contain money set
aside for contingency purposes not to exceed ten percent (10%) of the total
budget, less the amount set aside for contingency purposes, which monies may be
expended for contingencies upon a majority vote of the Corporate Authorities
then holding office.
   F.   Public Inspection, Notice And Hearing On Budget:
      1.   The Corporate Authorities shall make the tentative annual budget
conveniently available to public inspection for at least ten (10) days prior to
the passage of the annual budget by publication in the "Journal" of the
proceedings of the Corporate Authorities or in such other form as the Corporate
Authorities may prescribe.
      2.   Not less than one (1) week after the publication of the tentative
annual budget, and prior to final action on the budget, the Corporate
Authorities shall hold at least one (1) public hearing on the tentative annual
budget, after which hearing or hearings the tentative annual budget may be
further revised and passed without any further inspection, notice or hearing.
      3.   Notice of the public hearing shall be given by publication in a
newspaper having a general circulation in the Village at least one (1) week
prior to the time of the hearing. (Ord. 2014-36, 11-25-2014)
1-10-5: BILLS; PAYROLL:
All bills payable by the Village, other than for the payment of salaries and
health insurance premiums, shall be submitted to the Board for approval before
payment except when time constraints mandate that a payment be made by manual
check before the next meeting of the Board. Such payment by manual check must
be authorized by one (1) of the following: Village President, Village
Administrator or Village Treasurer, and such payments shall not exceed five
thousand dollars ($5,000.00). In addition, all manual checks issued shall be
presented at the next Board meeting for ratification. (Ord. 2002-13, 3-26-2002)
1-10-6: SURETY BONDS:
   A.   Whenever a surety bond to indemnify the Village is required, the surety
on such bond shall be a corporation licensed and authorized to do business in
this State as a surety company.
   B.   Whenever in its opinion additional sureties or an additional surety may
be needed on any bond to indemnify the Village against loss or liability
because of the insolvency of the existing surety or sureties or for any other
reason, the Board may order a new surety or sureties to be secured for such
bond. If such new surety or sureties are not procured within ten (10) days from
the time such other is transmitted to the principal of the bond, or his
assignee, the Board shall declare the bond to be void and thereupon such
principal or assignee shall be deemed to have surrendered the privilege or
position as a condition of which the bond was required. (1975 Code § 1.07)
1-10-7: MUNICIPAL PURCHASING:
1-10-7-1: PURCHASING POLICY:
A Purchasing Policy is hereby established for the Village and said policy is
found in a separate compilation as adopted by resolution 2017-R-20 copies of
which shall be kept on file with the Village Clerk. (Ord. 2017-22, 6-27-2017)
1-10-7-2: PURCHASES OVER TWENTY THOUSAND DOLLARS:
   A.   Public Improvements: Any work or other public improvement which is not
to be paid for in whole or in part by special assessment or special taxation,
when the expense thereof will exceed twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00),
shall be considered either: 1) by a contract let to the lowest responsible
bidder after advertising for bids, in the manner prescribed by ordinance,
except that any such contract may be entered into by the proper officers
without advertising for bids, if authorized by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of
all the Trustees then holding office; or 2) in the following manner if
authorized by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of all the Trustees then holding
office: The Supervisor of Streets or Superintendent of Sewers or other proper
officer designated by the Board of Trustees shall superintend and cause to be
carried out the construction of the work of other public improvement and shall
employ exclusively for the performance of all manual labor thereon, laborers
and artisans whom the Village shall pay by the day or hour, and all material of
the value of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) and upward used in the
construction of the work or other public improvement shall be purchased by
contract let to the lowest responsible bidder in the manner to be prescribed by
ordinance. However, nothing contained in this subsection shall apply to any
contract with the Federal government or any agency thereof. (Ord. 2017-22, 6-
27-2017; amd. Ord. 2024-49, 10-8-2024)
1-10-7-3: BIDDING PROCEDURE:
   A.   Publication: All proposals to award purchase orders or contracts in
excess of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) pursuant to section
1-10-7-2 of this chapter shall be published once at least ten (10) days in
advance of the date announced for the receiving of bids in at least one (1)
newspaper of general circulation throughout the Village by the Clerk. Nothing
herein shall be construed to prohibit the Clerk from posting additional notices
or advertising in addition thereto in trade magazines, if so directed by the
Board of Trustees.
   B.   Notice Of Call For Bids: Advertisements for bids shall describe the
character of the proposed contract, purchase or improvement in sufficient
detail to enable the bidders thereon to know what their obligations will be,
either in the advertisement itself, or by reference to detailed plans and
specifications on file in the Office of the Clerk at the time of publication of
the announcement. The advertisement shall also state the date, time and place
assigned for the opening of bids, and such bids will be received at any time
subsequent to the time indicated in the announcement.
   C.   Deposit On Bids: Cash, a cashier's check, certified check or bid bond
as a deposit of good faith, in a reasonable amount, but not in excess of ten
percent (10%) of the contract or purchase amount, may be required of each
bidder on all sums in excess of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) if
specified in the bid announcement.
   D.   Opening Of Sealed Bids: All sealed bids shall be publicly opened by the
Village Clerk at a public meeting. All bids shall be open to public inspection
in the Office of the Clerk for a period of forty eight (48) hours before the
award is made.
   E.   Bid Award: The award of any purchase or contract in excess of twenty-
five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) shall be made by the Board of Trustees to
the lowest responsible bidder.
   F.   Determining Responsibility Of Bidders: In determining the
responsibility of any bidder, the Village Board may take into account other
factors in addition to financial responsibility, such as past records of
transactions with the bidder, experience, adequacy of equipment, ability to
complete performance within the specified time limit, and other pertinent
considerations. In addition, the Village Board may waive irregularities in any
bid and may reject any and all bids in its discretion.
   G.   Bids When Not Required: Nothing contained herein shall prohibit the
Village from obtaining bids for contracts, supplies, work or public
improvements when such bids are not required by this chapter. Where such bids
are obtained although not required, contracts may be awarded to any bidder or
even to a nonbidder by the Board of Trustees when the Board of Trustees
believes that such award is in the best interests of the Village.
   H.   Contracts Not Assignable: No contract awarded to the lowest responsible
bidder shall be assignable by the successful bidder without the consent of the
Village Board of Trustees expressed by resolution.
   I.   Participation In Statewide Bid Program Or Purchasing Cooperatives: In
purchases of equipment, vehicles and supplies, the Village may participate in
statewide bid programs or in purchasing cooperatives such as the Suburban
Purchasing Cooperative whereby bidding is done by a separate entity in order to
achieve savings due to volume purchasing. Where the Village elects to so
participate, no separate bidding process need be undertaken by the Village, and
a motion to authorize and approve a purchase through such an organization shall
satisfy any and all requirements of this section and of the Village's
Purchasing Policy described in section
1-10-7-1 of this chapter. (Ord. 2017-22, 6-27-2017; amd. Ord. 2024-49, 10-8-
2024)
1-10-7-4: CONFLICTS:
In the event of any conflict between any provisions of the Village's Purchasing
Policy and any provisions in a State of Illinois Statute or this section
1-10-7, the following shall apply: The provisions in any State of Illinois
Statute shall prevail in any conflict with any Village ordinance that pertains
to purchasing and the provisions of any Village ordinance shall prevail in any
conflict with any provision in the Village's Purchasing Policy. (Ord. 2017-22,
6-27-2017)
1-10-7-5: INVESTMENT POLICY:
An Investment Policy is hereby established for the Village and said policy is
found in a separate compilation as adopted by resolution 2014 R 63, copies of
which shall be kept on file with the Village Clerk. (Ord. 2017-22, 6-27-2017)
CHAPTER 11
REVENUE BONDS
SECTION:
1-11-1: Applicability
1-11-2: Application; Fee, Review
1-11-3: Inducement Resolution
1-11-4: Final Procedures
1-11-5: Fee For Issuance Of Bonds
1-11-1: APPLICABILITY:
Whenever the Village receives a request that the Village participate in an
industrial or commercial development by the issuance of revenue bonds according
to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-74-1 et seq., the procedures of this
chapter shall apply. (Ord. 80-40, 11-17-1980)
1-11-2: APPLICATION; FEE, REVIEW:
   A.   Application; Fee: Upon request, the Village Clerk shall furnish a
sample application which shall describe the information required for review by
the Village. Said application shall be filed in quadruplicate with the Village
Clerk and shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee in the sum of
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Special meeting expense shall be in
addition to the application fee. (Ord. 80-40, 11-17-1980)
   B.   Review By Economic Development Strategic Planning Team: One (1) copy of
such application shall be furnished to the Economic Development Strategic
Planning Team. The Economic Development Strategic Planning Team shall review
and examine the application and shall make recommendations to the President and
Board of Trustees concerning the economic viability of the proposed
development.
   C.   Review By Planning And Zoning Commission: One (1) copy of such
application shall be furnished to the Planning and Zoning Commission. The
Planning and Zoning Commission shall review the application and shall make
recommendations to the President and Board of Trustees concerning the
suitability of the proposed development as part of the overall plan for the
Village. (Ord. 2017-23, 5-9-2017)
   D.   Additional Information: If the President and Board of Trustees or any
of the above bodies request additional information from the applicant, then no
final action shall be taken on the application until such additional
information is supplied in satisfactory form. (Ord. 80-40, 11-17-1980; amd.
Ord. 2017-23, 5-9-2017)
1-11-3: INDUCEMENT RESOLUTION:
At least seven (7) days prior to final action, bond counsel for the developer
shall furnish to the Village legal counsel a copy of the proposed inducement
resolution by which the Village approved the development and issuance of bonds
in principal. Such inducement resolution shall require the affirmative vote of
three-fifths (3/5) of the Corporate Authorities for passage. (Ord. 80-40, 11-
17-1980)
1-11-4: FINAL PROCEDURES:
Final approval by the President and Board of Trustees shall occur following
preparation of all agreements, security instruments, guaranties and other
documents by the developer's bond counsel, and furnishing of copies of said
items to the Village legal counsel at least seven (7) days prior to final
action. No final action may be taken without the affirmative vote of three-
fifths (3/5) of the Corporate Authorities. (Ord. 80-40, 11-17-1980)
1-11-5: FEE FOR ISSUANCE OF BONDS:
The Village's fee for issuing any such bonds shall be one-half of one percent
(0.5%) of the amount of the bond issue, but in no event shall such fee exceed
ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). Said fee shall be payable in full
immediately following passage of final action by the President and Board of
Trustees approving issuance of bonds. Wherever practicable, fees collected
hereunder shall be used to defray the Village's expenses incurred in analyzing
the impact of the development on the Village, and processing the issuance of
bonds, and in otherwise promoting economic and industrial development in and
near the Village. (Ord. 80-40, 11-17-1980)
CHAPTER 12
PUBLIC SAFETY EMPLOYEE BENEFITS ACT ADMINISTRATION
SECTION:
1-12-1: Purpose
1-12-2: Application Procedure
1-12-3: Application Review By The Human Resources Department And/Or Village
Administrator
1-12-4: Hearing Officer/Hearing
1-12-5: Administrative Hearing
1-12-6: Administrative Review
1-12-7: Health Insurance Benefits
1-12-8: Other Health Insurance Benefits
1-12-1: PURPOSE:
   A.   The general purpose of this chapter is to establish the process by
which an individual can apply for health insurance benefits pursuant to PSEBA
and is intended to provide a fair and efficient method of determining the
eligibility of a full-time village of Fox Lake police officers to the benefits
enumerated under the Act through an administrative process, including if
necessary, an administrative hearing. All benefits provided to employees
pursuant to PSEBA shall be consistent with the Act.
   B.   The administrative procedure established herein recognizes the
village's obligations under PSEBA to provide health insurance benefits to
eligible individuals as provided under PSEBA, who qualify for, and are
determined to be eligible to receive, certain health insurance benefits from
the village. This administrative procedure is not a contract that bestows a
benefit or entitlement on any particular individual and may be modified by the
village at any time without notice.
   C.   Any full-time village police officer who, after the effective date of
PSEBA, suffers a catastrophic injury or is killed in the line of duty, and
which injury or death occurred as the result of the officer's response to fresh
pursuit, the officer's response to what is reasonably believed to be an
emergency, an unlawful act perpetrated by another, or during the investigation
of a criminal act, may apply for health insurance benefits under PSEBA as set
forth in this chapter. The same benefits may be extended to the spouse and
eligible dependent children of the catastrophically injured or deceased public
safety employee, provided the conditions as established by PSEBA are met. (Ord.
2020-20, 9-22-2020)
1-12-2: APPLICATION PROCEDURE:
A PSEBA application shall be filed by a PSEBA applicant no later than thirty
(30) days from the date a permanent line-of-duty disability pension claim is
awarded. Any police chief who is not subject to the jurisdiction of the Police
or Fire Pension Board shall submit a completed PSEBA application within six (6)
months of sustaining the alleged catastrophic injury.
The Village Administrator shall provide the applicant with a copy of this
section at the time the PSEBA application is provided.
   A.   The application shall include the name of the employee; the full name
of the applicant's spouse, date of marriage, with marriage license attached;
birth certificates or adoption orders for all dependent children, and any and
all other documents establishing that the child is "dependent" as set forth in
the village's health insurance plan document; the date of hire; detailed
information regarding the incident including date, time, place and nature of
injury, and any other factual circumstances surrounding the incident giving
rise to said claim; the identities of witnesses to the incident, the names of
witnesses the applicant may call at a PSEBA hearing and the names and addresses
of the employee's medical providers; information and supporting documentation
filed with the Pension Board by the applicant and all exhibits on file with the
Pension Board; any and all rulings or determinations by the Pension Board; any
and all documents supporting the PSEBA eligibility requirement for applicant's
beneficiaries, including: proof of active school enrollment and employment.
Failure to file a fully complete application, along with submittal of all
supporting documents, shall result in a forfeiture of PSEBA benefits until the
next date of open enrollment for the insurance.
   B.   Medical Release Required: Medical records shall be secured by the
village. Medical releases provided by the Village Administrator authorizing the
collection of medical information by the village related to the injury
incident, including, but not limited to, disability pension proceedings,
worker's compensation records and medical records shall be signed by the
applicant and timely submitted with the PSEBA application. The PSEBA medical
release shall specify the name, address, email and phone information for all
pertinent health care providers and hospitals, along with the employee's
signature and a witness's signature. The release shall comply with HIPAA
standards. Medical records shall be considered "supporting documents" as
required above.
   C.   Additional Information: The Human Resources Department shall, at any
time, have the authority to modify the PSEBA application, or seek additional
information from an applicant, to better enable the village to ascertain the
applicant's qualifications.
   D.   No Review Until Complete Application Filed: The village's initial
review of the PSEBA application will not occur until all of the required
information, including the supporting documents, are submitted to the Human
Resources Department.
   E.   Sworn Application: Any application for PSEBA benefits shall be sworn to
by the applicant and notarized. All supporting documents filed for PSEBA
qualification shall be verified under oath by the applicant and notarized.
(Ord. 2020-20, 9-22-2020; amd. Ord. 2022-49, 8-23-2022)
1-12-3: APPLICATION REVIEW BY THE HUMAN RESOURCES    DEPARTMENT AND/OR VILLAGE
ADMINISTRATOR:
Upon receipt of a timely fully completed PSEBA application filed, the village's
Human Resources Department will review the application form and associated
materials in order to determine whether the applicant is eligible for PSEBA
benefits. If Human Resources staff members decide that additional information
is necessary in order to render a decision, staff members may schedule an
informal meeting with the applicant and/or the applicant's representative.
Alternatively, Human Resources staff members may schedule a formal fact-finding
hearing pursuant to the procedures outlined in section
1-12-5  below. Human Resources staff members also may consult with other
individuals and/or resources as they deem appropriate.
   A.   HR Recommendation for PSEBA Benefits: In the event the Human Resources
Department concludes without a fact-finding hearing that the applicant is
entitled to PSEBA benefits, staff members will submit a recommendation for such
benefits to the Village Administrator.
   B.   PSEBA Approval: If the Village Administrator determines that all PSEBA
requirements have been satisfied, the Village Administrator may grant the PSEBA
benefits. Upon such grant, the applicant will be notified and required to
contact the Human Resources Department within thirty (30) calendar days for
benefit explanation and processing.
   C.   PSEBA Fact-Finding: If the Village Administrator does not approve the
application or decides that additional fact-gathering is necessary, the Village
Administrator may schedule a fact-finding hearing pursuant to the procedures
outlined in section
1-12-5  below.
   D.   Setting Initial Date: In the event that Human Resources staff members
and/or the Village Administrator conclude that a fact-finding hearing is
necessary in order to determine whether an applicant is eligible for PSEBA
benefits, the Village Administrator will appoint an Administrative Hearing
Officer within thirty (30) days of the request. The Administrative Hearing
Officer shall set the first date of the administrative hearing within thirty
(30) calendar days of being appointed. (Ord. 2020-20, 9-22-2020; amd. Ord.
2022-49, 8-23-2022)
1-12-4: HEARING OFFICER/HEARING:
   A.   Appointment of Hearing Officer: The Village Administrator is hereby
authorized to appoint one or more persons to hold the position of
Administrative Hearing Officer for any village PSEBA administrative hearing. In
making this selection, the Village Administrator shall consider all of the
pertinent information, including at a minimum:
      1.   The candidate's ability to completely perform the services;
      2.   The candidate's background, service and performance data on file
with the village or otherwise obtained by the village; and
      3.   The candidate shall:
         a.   be an attorney licensed to practice law in the state of Illinois
for at least three years prior to appointment or an arbitrator who is a member
of the National Academy of Arbitrators; and
         b.   have knowledge of and experience in employment and labor law,
general civil procedure, the rules of evidence, PSEBA and administrative
practice.
   B.   Power of the Hearing Officer: The Hearing Officer shall have all the
powers granted under common law relative to the conduct of an administrative
hearing, including the power to:
      1.   Preside over PSEBA hearing(s);
      2.   Administer oaths;
      3.   Provide official written notice via certified mail to the applicant
and/or his representative of the scheduling of a fact-finding hearing; the
notice will provide the date, time and location of such hearing;
      4.   Arrange for a court reporter, who will be responsible for
transcribing the contents of the fact-finding hearing;
      5.   Rule on motions to intervene from interested parties;
      6.   Inquire into all matters related to the applicant's entitlement to
PSEBA benefits;
      7.   Regulate all facets of the fact-finding hearing, including the
conduct of any parties and/or their counsel, the length of the hearing and the
number of witnesses;
      8.   Receive relevant evidence in the form of testimony, exhibits or
stipulations. Insofar as practicable, the Hearing Officer will apply the rules
of evidence applicable in Illinois courts. However, the Hearing Officer is not
required to strictly follow the rules of evidence. Testimonial evidence shall
be taken only on oath or affirmation;
   9.   Establish reasonable limits on the frequency and duration of the
testimony of any witness;
      10.   Examine witnesses and direct witnesses to testify;
      11.   Rule on objections, motions and questions of procedure;
      12.   Authorize the submission of post-hearing briefs and set the time
for their filing;
      13.   Hear closing arguments; and
       14.   Issue written factual findings and a decision based on: each
element required under the Act to establish the applicant's qualifications, the
evidence presented at the hearing, the law, and after entertaining (oral or
written) arguments as directed by the Administrative Hearing Officer. (Ord.
2020-20, 9-22-2020; amd. Ord. 2022-49, 8-23-2022)
1-12-5: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING:
   A.   The administrative hearing shall be held to adjudicate and determine
whether the applicant is eligible for PSEBA benefits consistent with the Act
and this Ordinance and as follows:
      1.   Time and Date: Hearing shall be held on the date, time and place
established by the Administrative Hearing Officer with appropriate notice
served upon the applicant. The Administrative Hearing Officer may decide that
the failure of the applicant to attend a scheduled hearing may result in
forfeiture of benefits.
      2.   Hearing Transcription: The village shall secure the attendance of a
certified court reporter to make a transcript of all hearings. The village and
the applicant shall split equally the cost of the court reporter's appearance
fee and the cost of one transcript for the hearing officer. If the village or
the applicant requests their own copies of the transcript, they shall bear the
entire cost of their own copies.
      Normally, the transcript shall be prepared based on the court reporter's
standard, non-expedited time schedule. If one party requests an expedited
transcript, that party shall bear the entire amount of the increased cost for
the expedited transcripts, including the extra cost of any and all copies of
the expedited transcripts.
      3.   Procedures: The village and the applicant shall be entitled to
representation by counsel at said hearing and may present witnesses, testimony
and documents, cross-examine witnesses, and request the issuance of subpoenas
to compel appearances of witnesses and the production of relevant documents.
Each party shall bear its own costs of counsel and witnesses.
      4.   Evidence: The Illinois Rules of Evidence shall apply to the extent
practicable unless the Administrative Hearing Officer determines that
application of a rule would be an injustice or preclude the introduction of
evidence of the type commonly relied upon by a reasonably prudent person in the
conduct of their affairs. Such determination shall be in the sole discretion of
the Administrative Hearing Officer, but the Administrative Hearing Officer
shall state on the record the reason for that determination.
      5.   Burden of Proof: The applicant shall have the burden of proceeding
and the burden of proof to establish that the applicant and Applicant's
Beneficiaries are qualified to receive PSEBA benefits.
      6.   The determination of the applicant's eligibility for PSEBA benefits
shall constitute a final administrative determination for purposes of judicial
review.
      7.   Administrative Records: All records pertaining to the administrative
process will be held in a separate file in the employee's name in the village's
Human Resources Department. (Ord. 2020-20, 9-22-2020)
1-12-6: ADMINISTRATIVE REVIEW:
The Administrative Hearing Officer's determination shall be subject to a common
law writ of certiorari by the applicant or the village. (Ord. 2020-20, 9-22-
2020)
1-12-7: HEALTH INSURANCE BENEFITS:
Upon qualification for PSEBA benefits, the beneficiary shall be entitled to
receive health insurance benefits to the extent provided by law under PSEBA.
   A.   Open Enrollment: Applicants receiving benefits under PSEBA shall
annually complete a PSEBA extension application provided by the Village
Administrator no later than thirty (30) days prior to the end date of all
village open enrollment periods. This requirement shall also apply to all
individuals who first began receiving PSEBA benefits prior to passage of this
chapter. (Ord. 2020-20, 9-22-2020; amd. Ord. 2022-49, 8-23-2022)
1-12-8: OTHER HEALTH INSURANCE BENEFITS:
   A.   Other Benefits: Health insurance benefits payable from any other source
will reduce the benefits payable from the village. Each applicant shall sign an
affidavit annually attesting that the applicant is not eligible for insurance
benefits from any other source, unless there is another source. If there is
another source, the applicant shall notify the village of that source no later
than five (5) business days from that source becoming available to the
applicant or the applicant's beneficiaries.
   B.   Disclosure of Health Insurance Coverage: The applicant has an on-going
obligation and shall update health insurance coverage information provided and
failure to do so may result in the denial of benefits and/or reimbursement to
the village for duplicate coverage. If duplicate coverage has been received by
a PSEBA beneficiary, further PSEBA benefits will be denied until the village
has been fully reimbursed by the PSEBA beneficiary for what it would have been
credited if it had known about other coverage.
   C.   Reimbursement: Receipt of health insurance benefits from other sources
without notice to the village shall require the applicant to reimburse the
village for the value of those benefits.
   D.   Medicare Eligibility: The applicant shall notify the village when the
applicant becomes Medicare eligible regardless of the status of the enrollment
period, so the village may assist with the transition to Medicare coverage and/
or adjust health insurance benefits or PSEBA benefits accordingly. (Ord. 2020-
20, 9-22-2020)

CHAPTER 3
BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS
SECTION:
2-3-1: Creation; Members
2-3-2: Qualification; Oath; Bond
2-3-3: Powers and Duties
2-3-4: Secretary
2-3-1: CREATION; MEMBERS:
There is hereby created a Board of Fire and Police Commissioners consisting of
three (3) members as provided by statute, 1  whose terms of office shall be
three (3) years; except that one of the members when first appointed shall be
appointed to serve until the end of the current Municipal year at passage of
these provisions, another to serve until the end of the Municipal year next
ensuing, and the third to serve until the end of the Municipal year second next
ensuing. All members shall serve until their respective successors are
appointed and have qualified. They shall be subject to removal from office as
such other officers.
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. ch. 24, §10-2.1-1.
2-3-2: QUALIFICATION; OATH; BOND:
Members of the Board shall possess the qualifications required of other
officers of the Village, shall take oath or affirmation of office and give bond
in the same manner as other appointive officers of the Village. 1
 
Notes
1 2. See Title 1, Chapter 8 of this Code. 2-3-3
2-3-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall appoint all members of
the Fire and Police Departments of the Village except the Chief of Police and
the Chief of the Fire Department, which appointments shall be made by the
Village President and Board of Trustees. The Chief of Police and the Chief of
the Fire Department shall not be subject to this Chapter, nor to the rules made
by the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners pursuant to the authority
hereinafter granted. All appointments made by the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners shall be from the rank next below that to which the appointment
shall be made, other than that of the lowest rank.
   B.   Such Board of Commissioners shall make such rules and make such
appointments and removals except those herein reserved to the Village President
and Board of Trustees, and shall have such other and further powers as are
contained in division 2, section 10 of chapter 24 of the Illinois Revised
Statutes, and any and all amendments thereto.
2-3-4: SECRETARY:
Such Board may employ a secretary or may designate one of its own members to
act as secretary. The secretary shall keep the minutes of the Board's meetings,
shall be custodian of all papers pertaining to the business of the Board, shall
keep a record of all examinations held and shall perform such other duties as
the Board may prescribe. (Ord. 78-9, 3-20-78)
CHAPTER 4
BUILDING BOARD OF APPEALS
SECTION:
2-4-1: Established; Members
2-4-2: Duties
2-4-1: ESTABLISHED; MEMBERS:
   A.   There is hereby established a building board of appeals in conformity
with the provisions of the various codes adopted by the village related to
