8-2-2: PROHIBITED CONDUCT IN VILLAGE PARKS:
   A.   Applicability And Prohibition: The rules set forth in subsection B of
this section are established for the following official Village parks under the
jurisdiction of the Village of Fox Lake's Parks and Recreation Department:
      1.   18 East Grand Avenue Park;
      2.   Community Garden and Community Garden Green;
      3.   Eagle Point Park;
      4.   Grace Avenue Park;
      5.   King's Island Park;
      6.   Lakefront Park;
      7.   Millennium Park;
      8.   Round Hill Park;
      9.   Veterans Memorial Park; and
      10.   2 East Grand Avenue Park.
   Violation of any of the rules set forth in subsection B of this section is
hereby prohibited.
   B.   Rules: The following rules shall apply:
      1.   No alcohol (unless permitted by the Village).
      2.   No swimming (unless permitted by the Village). Fishing in designated
areas only.
      3.   No fires including fires for charcoal grilling but propane grilling
is allowed.
      4.   No watercraft launching.
      5.   Park hours are eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to dusk. Building hours are
eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to ten o'clock (10:00) P.M.
      6.   No littering.
      7.   All pets must be leashed and owners must clean up any droppings.
Only service animals are allowed in Village owned buildings.
      8.   All Village recreational programs have priority in the park and the
use of the park facilities.
      9.   No trailer parking unless permitted. Parking of vehicles is allowed
in designated areas only.
      10.   Commuter parking is strictly prohibited (commuters will be ticketed
and towed at owner's expense).
      11.   No staples, nails or any type of fastener on any park building,
trees, no signage.
      12.   No motorized vehicles in the park unless the area is designated for
parking or loading.
      13.   No stone throwing, hitting of golf balls, or any type of projectile
firing device into water.
      14.   No fireworks (including sparklers).
      15.   No discharge of chemical pollutants into the water or park areas.
      16.   Children under the age of five (5) to be accompanied by adult in
restrooms or port-o-potties.
      17.   No vandalism to buildings, vegetation, trees, or landscaping.
      18.   Gambling is prohibited.
      19.   No snowmobiles or all-terrain vehicles.
      20.   No access to railroad right-of-way from Lakefront Park.
      21.   No overnight boat parking at the Municipal piers.
      22.   No fishing, diving or swimming off of the Municipal piers.
      23.   No smoking of cigarettes, cigars, pipes or any tobacco products or
cannabis in any Village park except that cigarettes, cigars, pipes, or other
tobacco products, excluding cannabis, may be smoked in Village parks in smoking
areas designated by signage installed by the Village.
      24.   No erection of permanent structures on park property by park
patrons and no erection of temporary structures which are enclosed on more than
three (3) sides, whether they be made of rigid or pliable or cloth-like
materials, unless said materials are transparent.
      25.   No bottles or other containers made of glass allowed on park
property.
      26.   No personal property shall be allowed to remain in Village Parks at
such times as said Village Parks are closed. Any such personal property allowed
to remain shall be subject to removal and disposal by Village representatives.
      27.   Hanging or placing of articles of clothing or bedding on any
facilities or structures.
      The above rules shall be enforceable in Village Parks and buildings
whether or not they are posted on the property.
   C.   Penalties: Any person found guilty of violating any rules set forth in
this section shall be fined as follows:
      1.   First offense: Fifty dollars ($50.00) (petty offense).
      2.   Second offense: One hundred dollars ($100.00).
      3.   Third and succeeding offenses: Not less than two hundred dollars
($200.00) and not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
      4.   In addition to the above fines, restitution may be required by the
court for the cost of repairing damage to Village property.
      5.   For a violation of Section
8-2-2 B.27., a person found guilty or liable shall be subject to a fine of
$50.00. For all subsequent offenses, any persona property used in violation of
this Section shall be subject to removal and disposal by the Village.
   D.   Private Use Of Parks: The Village may permit private use of the
facilities identified in subsection A of this section on a reserved basis
subject to the following provisions:
      1.   Fees charged shall be in accordance with a schedule approved by the
Board of Trustees and maintained by the Parks and Recreation Coordinator.
      2.   Forms for reservation shall be available from the Parks and
Recreation Coordinator.
      3.   The Village may require a security deposit which may be forfeited if
terms of the reservation are not complied with.
   E.   Outdoor Public Ice Skating Rink: The Village staff may from time to
time construct and maintain an outdoor public ice skating rink and the rules,
policies and regulations for such ice skating rink are hereby established as
follows:
      1.   Fox Lake Recreation Area Outdoor Public Ice Skating Rink Rules,
Policies, And Regulations:
         a.   The Village of Fox Lake Outdoor Ice Rink is constructed and
maintained by the Village of Fox Lake. Outdoor ice has imperfections not
normally encountered on indoor rinks. Like all sports and recreational
activities, ice skating can be dangerous.
         b.   By visiting the rink you are acknowledging such and are skating
at your own risk.
         c.   All rules, policies and regulations of the outdoor public ice
skating ice rink and ordinances of the Village of Fox Lake must be adhered to.
         d.   For emergencies call 911 or for non-emergency help please call
(847) 587-3100.
         e.   Report any defects or hazardous conditions immediately to the
Village at (847) 587-3100.
         f.   Hours may vary due to weather and conditions, snow and ice at
rink. Staff has the discretion to close early if attendance is low or unsafe
ice conditions exist.
      2.   Open And Closing Notice Procedures:
         a.   On-Site:
            (1)   The ice rink will be open when a green flag is present.
            (2)   The ice will be closed when a red flag is present.
         b.   Via Social Media And Internet:
            (1)   Status will be posted daily on the Village of Fox Lake Parks
and Recreation Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/VFLparksandrec/.
            (2)   Status will be posted daily on the Village website in the
"spotlight news" section at: website www.foxlake.org/.
      3.   Hours For The Ice Rink (Subject To Change):
 
Public skate:          Daily 10:00 A.M. to 8:30 P.M.
                       Hockey/sticks and pucks are prohibited on the ice
Hockey/stick and puck: Daily 8:30 P.M. to 11:00 P.M.
                       No figure skating unless hockey is not present
 
      4.   General Ice Rink Rules:
         a.   On warm days, stay off the ice;
         b.   Please respect the "status" signs (red means closed, green means
open);
         c.   No skating or trespassing when the ice rink is closed;
         d.   Keep the rink clean - please place trash in receptacles on-site;
         e.   No glass;
         f.   No food or drink on ice surface;
         g.   No smoking on or around the ice rink;
         h.   Drugs and alcohol are strictly prohibited;
         i.   No pets are permitted at the Village of Fox Lake Outdoor Ice
Rink;
         j.   Refrain from offensive language and behavior;
         k.   No chipping, throwing or spraying ice;
         l.   Share the ice, be courteous to other skaters around you;
         m.   Helmets are required;
         n.   Do not sit on, hang over or leave articles on the sideboards;
         o.   Parent or guardian must accompany children under the age of
twelve (12);
         p.   No children under the age of three (3) allowed on ice;
         q.   Games are not permitted that will interfere with other skaters
(broom ball, etc.);
         r.   Tag, horseplay, speed skating, jumping, backwards skating or
weaving across traffic is not allowed during public sessions;
         s.   Hockey sticks and pucks are not permitted during public skate;
         t.   No more than two (2) skaters may join hands while skating;
         u.   No chain skating.
      5.   Policy And Procedures:
         a.   The Village of Fox Lake Ice Rink is unsupervised;
         b.   The Village of Fox Lake reserves the right to close the rink at
any time. Rink will be closed for inclement weather, rain, ice or snow;
         c.   Organized events are not allowed unless scheduled in conjunction
with the Village of Fox Lake and appropriate agreements and arrangements are in
place;
         d.   The Village of Fox Lake reserves the right to expel anyone from
the park for a violation of the rules;
         e.   Violation of these rules may result in permanent revocation of
skating privileges;
         f.   The Village of Fox Lake is not responsible for lost or stolen
belongings;
         g.   The user assumes full responsibility for determining if the ice
is safe to use;
         h.   Rules may change to provide safe skating for all to enjoy.
      6.   Hockey/Stick And Puck Rules:
         a.   Each player must provide their own equipment;
         b.   Full equipment is required;
         c.   Full face shields are required;
         d.   There are to be no small/full ice games during stick and puck;
         e.   Be aware of those around you when handling pucks;
         f.   Fighting and horseplay will not be tolerated;
         g.   Fighting will result in expulsion without refund and possible
banishment from the rink;
         h.   No alcohol or tobacco use is permitted on the premises;
         i.   Violation will be grounds for expulsion and banishment from the
rink and park;
         j.   It is not the responsibility of the rink to provide pucks or
equipment;
         k.   Users are required to wear helmets and other protective gear.
   Failure to comply with any of the rules will result in the immediate and
potential loss of future use of the outdoor rink. In addition, the penalties
set forth in subsection C of this section shall apply to violations of this
section.
(Ord. 2011-07, 1-25-2011; amd. Ord. 2012-16, 7-10-2012; Ord. 2018-49, 11-13-
2018; Ord. 2020-01, 1-28-2020; Ord. 2024-31, 6-25-2024; Ord. 2024-36, 7-23-
2024; Ord. 2024-42, 9-10-2024; Ord. 2025-15, 5-13-2025)
8-2-3: TRAFFIC AND PARKING ACTIVITIES ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
   A.   Applicability: This section shall apply to any and all parcels of
private property whose owners have entered into an agreement with the Village
pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-209.
   B.   Handicapped Parking Areas:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to park a vehicle
or to leave a vehicle unattended in any area designated by the owner thereof or
the Corporate Authorities as handicapped parking, unless either the driver or a
passenger in the vehicle is a handicapped person. Any property owner reserving
a portion of a parking area for handicapped parking is deemed to have granted
to the Municipal Corporate Authorities the right to enforce this parking
restriction. A handicapped person is a person whose vehicle possesses
handicapped license plates issued by the State, or who has obtained a sticker
for display on said vehicle from the Village Police Department to be issued to
handicapped persons. (Ord. 88-42, 11-7-1988)
      2.   Any person violating any provisions of this subsection B shall be
assessed a fine in the amount of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00)
for each offense and any such person may have his vehicle towed from any
parking area designated as a handicapped parking area. The owner or operator of
any vehicle so towed shall be responsible for all charges incurred for such
removal and storage of said vehicle. (Ord. 2000-21, 6-5-2000)
   C.   Fire Lanes:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to park a vehicle
or to leave a vehicle unattended in any area designated by the owner thereof or
the Corporate Authorities as a fire lane, unless the driver or a passenger in
the vehicle is an emergency vehicle responding to an emergency. Any property
owner reserving a portion of a parking area for a fire lane is deemed to have
granted to the Municipal Corporate Authorities the right to enforce this
parking restriction. (Ord. 88-42, 11-7-1988)
      2.   Any person violating any provisions of this subsection C shall be
assessed a fine in the amount of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) for each
offense and any such person may have his vehicle towed from any parking area
designated as a fire lane. The owner or operator of any vehicle so towed shall
be responsible for all charges incurred for such removal and storage of said
vehicle. (Ord. 2000-21, 6-5-2000)
   D.   Stop Signs:
      1.   Wherever a stop sign is erected at an exit from private property to
a street in the village, the operator of a vehicle approaching such a stop sign
shall stop as required by law before entering said street.
      2.   Any person found guilty of violating subsection D1 of this section
shall be fined in an amount of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) and
not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 88-42, 11-7-1988)
   E.   Penalty:
      1.   In the event that the owner or operator of the vehicle does not pay
the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a violation of subsection B2 of
this section within a fifteen (15) day period from the time that the notice of
violation is attached to such vehicle, the police department shall send notice
to the registered owner of the vehicle that the fine has not been received
within said fifteen (15) day period and if it is not paid within fifteen (15)
days from the date of issuance of said notice, a warrant will be issued for the
arrest of the operator or owner.
      2.   In the event that the owner or operator of the vehicle does not pay
the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for a violation of subsection C2 of this
section within a fifteen (15) day period from the time that the notice of
violation is attached to such vehicle, the police department shall send notice
to the registered owner of the vehicle that the fine has not been received
within said fifteen (15) day period and if it is not paid within fifteen (15)
days from the date of issuance of said notice, a warrant will be issued for the
arrest of the operator or owner. (Ord. 2000-21, 6-5-2000)
8-2-4: OPERATION OF MOTOR VEHICLES ON WATERS AND FROZEN WATERS:
   A.   Definitions:
   MOTOR VEHICLE: Every vehicle which is self- propelled, including, but not
limited to: automobiles, trucks, snowmobiles, boats and motor driven cycles.
   OPERATE: To use, drive or control a motor vehicle.
   WATERS OF THE VILLAGE: Any and all waters, frozen or unfrozen, within the
boundaries of the village.
   B.   Registration Requirements:
      1.   All motor vehicles operating upon waters of the village shall be:
         a.   Registered by the Illinois department of conservation under the
Illinois boating registration and safety act.
         b.   Registered by the Illinois department of conservation under the
Illinois snowmobile registration and safety act.
         c.   Owned or used by the United States, state of Illinois, county of
Lake or the village of Fox Lake.
         d.   Registered by the secretary of state.
      2.   Any person found guilty of operating a motor vehicle upon waters of
the village when such vehicle is not registered, shall be deemed guilty of a
violation of this section.
   C.   Racing Events: No person shall promote, organize, advertise, conduct,
officiate at or participate as a contestant in any event in which motor
vehicles have races on the waters of the village without first securing a
permit from the village clerk as hereinafter set forth.
      1.   Application for permit shall be in writing and shall contain the
following information:
         a.   Name, address and telephone number of each promoter of the event
(including name, address and telephone number of each officer of a corporate
promoter).
         b.   Name, address and telephone number of each participant in the
event.
         c.   Name, address and telephone number of each person designated to
officiate at the event.
         d.   The date, time and place for the event.
         e.   Affidavit of a promoter or officer of a corporate promoter that
the application contains the above information in complete and accurate form.
      2.   Application for permit shall be accompanied by the following:
         a.   Payment of permit fee of fifty dollars ($50.00).
         b.   Certificate of insurance for each participant showing liability
coverage in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) to three
hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00).
         c.   Copy of registration for each motor vehicle to be used by any
participant in the event.
         d.   Copy of rules and regulations established to govern and control
the competition.
         e.   Certificate of insurance showing umbrella liability coverage for
the event with limits of at least one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00)
and with the Village as one of the insureds on the policy.
         f.   Diagrams showing the racing layout plus plans for crowd control,
parking and protective devices for spectators. In the event said plans are
deemed insufficient, then the Chief of Police shall either refuse to issue the
permit or shall require the insurance limits under subparagraph e hereof to be
increased to ten million dollars ($10,000,000.00).
   D.   Penalties: Any person found guilty of violating any provision of
subsection B of this Section shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars
($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each such offense.
Any person found guilty of violating any provision of subsection C of this
Section shall be fined not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 80-13, 3-17-80)
8-2-5: WEIGHT LIMITS:
   A.   No person shall drive or move, and no owner shall cause or knowingly
permit to be driven or moved, on any street within the Village, any vehicle or
vehicles of a size or weight exceeding the posted weight limitation.
   B.   The provisions of this Section covering weight and load shall not apply
to fire apparatus or to implements of husbandry temporarily moved upon the
highway or to vehicles operated under permits or franchises of the Illinois
Commerce Commission.
   C.   Any police officer having reason to believe that the weight of a
vehicle and load is unlawful, shall require the driver to stop and submit to a
weighing of the same, either by means of a portable or stationary scale. If
such scales are not available at the place where such vehicle is stopped, the
police officer shall require that such vehicle be driven to the nearest public
scales.
   D.   Whenever an officer, upon weighing a vehicle and load as above
provided, determines that the weight is unlawful, such officer shall require
the driver to stop the vehicle in a suitable place and remain standing until
such portion of the load is removed as may be necessary to reduce the gross
weight of such vehicle to the limit as is permitted under this Section, and
shall forthwith arrest the driver. All materials so unloaded shall be cared for
by the owner or operator of the vehicle at the risk of the owner or operator.
   E.   Any driver of a vehicle who fails or refuses to stop and submit the
vehicle and load to a weighing, or fails or refuses when directed by an officer
to stop the vehicle and otherwise comply with the provisions of this Section,
shall be fined as provided in this Code 1 .
   F.   Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of this
Section, the owner or driver, or both, of such vehicle, shall be deemed guilty
of such violation and either or both the owner or the driver of such vehicle
may be prosecuted for the violation. Any person convicted of such violation
shall be fined in an amount equal to two cents ($0.02) per pound for each pound
of excess weight when the excess is one ton or less; four cents ($0.04) per
pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds one ton and is one and one-half
(11/2) tons or less; six cents ($0.06) per pound of excess weight when the
excess exceeds one and one-half (11/2) tons and is two (2) tons or less; eight
cents ($0.08) per pound for each pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds
two (2) tons and is two and one-half (21/2) tons or less; and ten cents ($0.10)
per pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds two and one-half (21/2)
tons. If the violation complained of is based upon an overload of not more than
three hundred fifty (350) pounds on a single axle, and the defendant proves
that such violation resulted from an unavoidable shifting of the load carried
in the vehicle, the amount of the fine shall not exceed one dollar ($1.00).
(1975 Code §24.04)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section 1-4-1 of this Code.
8-2-6: SEAT BELTS REQUIRED, EXCEPTIONS:
   A.   Each driver and front seat passenger of a motor vehicle operated on a
street or highway in this State shall wear a properly adjusted and fastened
seat safety belt; except that, a child less than six (6) years of age shall be
protected as required pursuant to the Child Passenger Protection Act 1 . Each
driver of a motor vehicle transporting a child six (6) years of age or more,
but less than sixteen (16) years of age, in the front seat of the motor vehicle
shall secure the child in a properly adjusted and fastened seat safety belt.
   B.   Subsection A shall not apply to any of the following:
      1.   A driver or passenger frequently stopping and leaving the vehicle or
delivering property from the vehicle, if the speed of the vehicle between stops
does not exceed fifteen (15) miles per hour.
      2.   A driver or passenger possessing a written statement from a
physician that such person is unable, for medical or physical reasons, to wear
a seat safety belt.
      3.   A driver or passenger possessing an official certificate or license
endorsement issued by the appropriate agency in another state or country
indicating that the driver is unable, for medical, physical or other valid
reasons, to wear a seat safety belt.
      4.   A driver operating a motor vehicle in reverse.
      5.   A motor vehicle with a model year prior to 1965.
      6.   A motorcycle or motor-driven cycle.
      7.   A motorized pedalcycle.
      8.   A motor vehicle which is not required to be equipped with seat
safety belts under Federal law.
      9.   A motor vehicle operated by a rural letter carrier of the United
States Postal Service while performing duties as a rural letter carrier.
   C.   Failure to wear a seat safety belt in violation of this section shall
not be considered evidence of negligence, shall not limit the liability of an
insurer, and shall not diminish any recovery for damages arising out of the
ownership, maintenance, or operation of a motor vehicle.
   D.   A violation of this section shall be a petty offense and subject to a
fine not to exceed twenty five dollars ($25.00). (Ord. 85-34A, 10-7-1985)
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. ch. 95/2, §§1101 et seq.
8-2-7: PENALTIES:
Unless provided otherwise in any section of this title, any person, firm or
corporation convicted of the violation of any section of this title shall be
fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) for each offense. (Ord. 2018-24, 5-22-2018)
8-2-8: SCHOOL ZONE:
   A.   Speed Limits:
      1.   The maximum speed limit on Devlin Road, between Grand Avenue and
Route 59, be and is hereby established at twenty five (25) miles per hour,
except as hereinafter provided in subsection A2 of this section.
      2.   That portion of Devlin Road which is adjacent to the property
occupied by the Grant Community High School shall have as its maximum speed
limit twenty (20) miles per hour between seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and four
o'clock (4:00) P.M. on each school day when school children are present.
   B.   No-Passing Zone: Devlin Road, between Grand Avenue and Route 59, be and
is hereby declared a No-Passing Zone.
   C.   Posting Signs: The Village Department of Streets is hereby directed to
post the speed limits as hereinbefore established at all appropriate places on
Devlin Road and to further post Devlin Road as a No-Passing Zone. Devlin Road
should also be posted with signs that will give proper and due warning that a
school zone is being approached and shall indicate the school zone and the
maximum speed limit in effect during school days when school children are
present. (Ord. 93-33, 12-6-1993)
CHAPTER 3
RULES OF THE ROAD
SECTION:
8-3-1: Speed Limits
8-3-2: Negligent Or Careless Driving
8-3-3: U-Turns
8-3-4: Limitations On Permissible Turns
8-3-5: Through Streets And Stop Intersections
8-3-6: Clinging To Moving Vehicles
8-3-7: Toy Vehicles
8-3-8: Nonregistered Vehicles
8-3-9: Skateboards
8-3-1: SPEED LIMITS:
When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall drive a vehicle
in excess of the indicated speed limits on any streets, and unless otherwise
posted, the speed limit in a business district shall not exceed thirty (30)
miles per hour, and in a residential district shall not exceed twenty (20)
miles per hour. (1975 Code § 24.03)
8-3-2: NEGLIGENT OR CARELESS DRIVING:
It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle in the village in a careless or
negligent manner, or carelessly so as to endanger life or property. (1975 Code
§ 24.05)
8-3-3: U-TURNS:
No person operating a vehicle upon any street shall make a U-turn on any place
on such street, either at intersections or between intersections, if said
street is so posted. (1975 Code § 24.06)
8-3-4: LIMITATIONS ON PERMISSIBLE TURNS:
Where signs are erected at an intersection indicating "No Left Turn" or "No
Right Turn" or "No Entrance" or "Right Turn Only", the operator of a vehicle
approaching such a sign shall obey said sign and shall not operate his vehicle
in violation of said sign. The corporate authorities may erect such signs as
are from time to time required in the interest of promoting public safety.
(Ord. 96-25, 8-5-1996)
8-3-5: THROUGH STREETS AND STOP INTERSECTIONS:
   A.   All streets in the village presently having stop signs are hereby
designated as stop intersections. Where stop signs are erected at the entrance
to a through street and stop intersections, the operator of a vehicle
approaching a stop sign shall stop as required by law.
   B.   All present through streets in the village are hereby designated
through streets.
   C.   The village president and board of trustees may from time to time
designate other streets as through streets and stop intersections as they may
deem necessary. (1975 Code § 24.07)
8-3-6: CLINGING TO MOVING VEHICLES:
Any person riding upon any bicycle, motorcycle, coaster, sled, roller skates,
skateboard, or any toy vehicle shall not attach the same or himself to any
moving vehicle upon any roadway. No person shall ride on the running board,
fender or outside stop of any vehicle. (Ord. 2009-14, 6-9-2009)
8-3-7: TOY VEHICLES:
No person upon roller skates or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy
vehicle, or similar device shall go upon any roadway except while crossing a
street on a crosswalk and except upon streets set aside as play streets when
and as authorized by ordinance. (1975 Code § 24.13)
8-3-8: NONREGISTERED VEHICLES:
No person shall operate a nonregistered vehicle upon the public roads or
sidewalks within the village except as permitted in this section.
   A.   For purposes of this section, a "vehicle" is defined as a wheeled
object which is propelled otherwise than by the muscular power of man or animal
and except such as are run on rails or tracks.
   B.   Included within the definition of "vehicle" in this section are all-
terrain vehicles, off road motorcycles and motor driven scooters.
   C.   No person shall operate any vehicle of any kind or nature upon any
sidewalk within the village except for the purpose of crossing a sidewalk for
ingress or egress to a lawful driveway.
   D.   "Nonregistered" shall mean not registered with a valid registration
from the Illinois secretary of state for purposes of this section.
   E.   Exemptions from operation of this section are:
      1.   Any police vehicle, fire vehicle or village vehicle driven by an
employee in the course of his or her duties.
      2.   Motorized wheelchairs as defined in article II of the Illinois
vehicle code.
   F.   Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this
section shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). (Ord. 2003-48, 9-16-2003)
8-3-9: SKATEBOARDS:
No person shall operate, ride, ride upon or propel a skateboard in violation of
this section.
   A.   Definitions:
   PROPEL: The use of force to move or push forward whether manually or machine
powered.
   RIDE: To be carried or travel on a device.
   SKATEBOARD: A device consisting of a board mounted on small wheels used for
coasting or performing athletic stunts (manual or powered).
   B.   Public Property Prohibition: It shall be unlawful for any person to
operate, ride, ride upon, or propel a skateboard in any of the following public
locations:
      1.   Upon any public street, highway, sidewalk, parking lot, or other
public property of any kind within the following specifically defined area(s):
The area bounded to the north by the northerly right of way line of Riverview
Avenue extended easterly and westerly; to the east by the easterly right of way
line of Lakeside Lane extended northerly and southerly; to the south by the
southerly right of way line of Cypress Avenue, extended westerly; and to the
west by the shoreline of Pistakee Lake, Nippersink Lake and easterly channel
which connects said lakes, as depicted on the following map:
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/4c7a36e82c769ab3fa58c07bf3de74624e177e0c/
IMAGES/0-0-0-1929.png]
      2.   Village parking lots wherever located;
      3.   The surface of any streets or highways located within the village.
The only exception to the above prohibited areas shall be village owned bike
trails and designated skateboarding parks.
   C.   Private Property Prohibition: It shall be unlawful for any person to
operate, ride, or propel a skateboard upon any portion of private property
unless permission has been received from the owner, lessee or person in control
of that property.
   D.   Restrictions In Permitted Areas:
      1.   On nonrestricted publicly owned sidewalks and bike trails operators
or riders of skateboards shall yield the right of way to other pedestrians and
shall not endanger or interfere with normal pedestrian traffic on those
sidewalks and bike trails.
      2.   No person shall operate or ride upon a skateboard, rollerblades,
roller skates, or any means of any coaster device on any publicly used
ancillary structure, including, but not limited to, benches, gazebos, bike
racks, handrails, and curb bumpers.
   E.   Parental Responsibility: Any parent, guardian, custodian, or person in
control of, or responsible for any child under the age of sixteen (16) who
knowingly allows said child to violate the provisions of this section and who
has previously been advised of a prior violation or violations of this section
by the same child, shall be subject to prosecution under this section and the
penalties prescribed for violation of this section.
   F.   Penalties: The penalty for violating this section shall be the payment
to the village of Fox Lake of a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor
more than twenty dollars ($20.00) for the first offense, and not less than
twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than fifty dollars ($50.00) for the
second and repeated offenses. (Ord. 2009-14, 6-9-2009)
CHAPTER 4
STOPPING, STANDING OR PARKING
SECTION:
8-4-1: No Parking Places
8-4-2: Loading Zones
8-4-3: Alleys
8-4-4: Cabstands
8-4-5: Time Limited Parking
8-4-6: Parking On Private Property
8-4-7: Signs
8-4-8: Parking Vehicles For Sale
8-4-9: Limited Winter Parking And Plowing Or Shoveling Of Snow
8-4-10: Overnight Parking
8-4-11: Parking In Residential Districts
8-4-12: Responsibility Of Owner
8-4-13: Penalties For Parking Violations
8-4-14: Village Commuter Parking Lots
8-4-1: NO PARKING PLACES:
It shall be unlawful, at any time, to permit any vehicle to stand in any of the
following places, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or
in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control
device:
   A.   In any intersection.
   B.   In a crosswalk.
   C.   Upon any bridge or viaduct, or in any subway or tunnel or the approach
thereto.
   D.   Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty feet (30')
of a point of the curb immediately opposite the end of a safety zone.
   E.   Within thirty feet (30') of a traffic signal, beacon, or sign on the
approaching side.
   F.   Within twenty feet (20') of any intersection or crosswalk.
   G.   At any place where the standing of a vehicle will reduce the usable
width of the roadway for moving traffic to less than eighteen feet (18').
   H.   Within fifteen feet (15') of a fire hydrant.
   I.   At any place where the vehicle would block the use of a driveway.
   J.   Within fifty feet (50') of the nearest rail of a railroad grade
crossing.
   K.   Within twenty feet (20') of the driveway entrance to any fire
department station and on the side of the street opposite the entrance to any
such station, within seventy five feet (75') of such entrance when properly
signposted.
   L.   On any sidewalk or parkway.
   M.   At any place where official signs prohibit parking. (1975 Code § 24.09)
   N.   On any private property, the owner of which has entered into a contract
with the village pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-209, and which
property is posted with signs prohibiting parking in conformity with 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/18a-302. (Ord. 2003-08, 3-25-2003)
8-4-2: LOADING ZONES:
It shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to stand a passenger vehicle
for a period of time longer than is necessary for the loading or unloading of
passengers, not to exceed three (3) minutes, and for the driver to stand any
freight carrying vehicles for a period of time longer than is necessary to
load, unload and deliver materials, not to exceed thirty (30) minutes, in any
place designated by the village president and the board of trustees as a
loading zone and marked as such, or in any of the following designated places:
   A.   At any place not to exceed seventy five feet (75') along the curb
before the entrance to any hospital or hotel at any time.
   B.   At any place not to exceed seventy five feet (75') along the curb
before any entrance to a public building between eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and
six o'clock (6:00) P.M. except on Sunday.
   C.   Directly in front of the entrance to any theater at any time that the
theater is open for business. (1975 Code § 24.09)
8-4-3: ALLEYS:
No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or under such
conditions as to leave available less than ten feet (10') of the width of the
roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic, and no person shall stop,
stand or park a vehicle within an alley in such a position as to block the
driveway entrance to an abutting property. (1975 Code § 24.09)
8-4-4: CAB STANDS 1 :
No vehicle other than a licensed taxicab shall be parked in any area designated
by ordinance as a cab stand. (1975 Code § 24.09)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 3-7-10 of this code.
8-4-5: TIME LIMITED PARKING:
Except on Sundays or holidays, it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle for a
longer consecutive period of time than that designated between hours of eight
o'clock (8:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. in any area designated as a
limited parking area and so marked. (1975 Code § 24.09)
8-4-6: PARKING ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle on any private property without
the consent of the owner of the property. (1975 Code § 24.09)
8-4-7: SIGNS:
The chief of police or any other person authorized by the village president and
board of trustees shall cause signs to be posted in all areas where parking is
limited or prohibited, indicating such limitations or prohibitions. (1975 Code
§ 24.09)
8-4-8: PARKING VEHICLES FOR SALE:
It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle upon any street for the purpose of
displaying it for sale or to park any vehicle upon any business street from
which vehicle merchandise is peddled, or to park any vehicle upon any street
without state license plates upon it issued for such vehicle to the owner of
the vehicle in accordance with the Illinois Compiled Statutes. (1975 Code §
24.08)
8-4-9: LIMITED WINTER PARKING AND PLOWING OR SHOVELING OF SNOW:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any vehicle to park
said vehicle on any street in the village for a period longer than three (3)
minutes for the loading and/or unloading of passengers, or for thirty (30)
minutes for the loading and/or unloading of property at any time after snow
begins to fall and exceeds two inches (2") of thickness, and said prohibition
against parking shall continue until the snowplowing operations have ceased.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any individual or business, while snowplowing
or shoveling their sidewalks, driveways or another's sidewalk or driveway
within the corporate limits of the village, to push, place or shovel snow on or
across any street or sidewalk within the village. (Ord. 85-36, 11-4-1985)
8-4-10: OVERNIGHT PARKING:
It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any motor vehicle other than
an automobile, pickup truck or van to park the motor vehicle on any street in
the village between the hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. and seven o'clock
(7:00) A.M. (Ord. 84-21, 10-1-1984)
8-4-11: PARKING IN RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS:
It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle other than an automobile, motor
driven cycle, motor home, mini-motor home, van camper, pickup truck or van in
any area or district zoned residential in the village. House trailers for
living quarters are prohibited within the village except in a licensed mobile
home park. (Ord. 84-20, 10-1-1984)
8-4-12: RESPONSIBILITY OF OWNER:
The fact that a vehicle is registered in a person's name shall be prima facie
proof that such person is responsible for any violation of any parking
regulation of this chapter involving the vehicle. (1975 Code § 24.11)
8-4-13: PENALTIES FOR PARKING VIOLATIONS:
The owner or operator of any vehicle which is parked in violation of any
section of this chapter shall pay a fine as follows:
   A.   The sum of seventy five dollars ($75.00), if paid within thirty (30)
days of the time that the notice of violation is attached to such vehicle.
(Ord. 2015-33, 7-28-2015)
   B.   In the event that the owner or operator of the vehicle does not pay the
sum of seventy five dollars ($75.00) within the thirty (30) day period as
hereinbefore provided, the Police Department shall send notice to the
registered owner of the vehicle that the fine has not been received within the
thirty (30) day period and that, therefore, the fine has escalated to one
hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) and that if it is not paid within fifteen (15)
days from the date of issuance of said notice, a warrant will be issued for the
arrest of the operator or owner. Alternatively, the Police Department may issue
a notice to appear so that the violation will be presented and adjudicated
pursuant to the Village's administrative hearing procedures (chapter 7 of this
title). (Ord. 2015-33, 7-28-2015; amd. Ord. 2017-48, 10-24-2017)
   C.   In addition to the above penalties, the Village may have the vehicle
parked in violation of subsection
8-4-1N of this chapter towed by a commercial vehicle relocator pursuant to the
terms of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/18a-302. (Ord. 2015-33, 7-28-2015)
8-4-14: VILLAGE COMMUTER PARKING LOTS:
   A.   Established: There are hereby established certain Village commuter
parking lots for residents of the area described in the plats attached to the
ordinance codified herein on file in the Village Clerk's Office and which lots
shall be collectively designated as the Village commuter parking lots.
   B.   Use Of Lots: Said lots shall be used only by legally and currently
licensed vehicles under two and one-half (21/2) tons. No unauthorized vehicle
or inoperable or disabled vehicle may be placed in any commuter parking lot.
(Ord. 86-46, 12-1-1986)
   C.   Fees: The parking rates for each parking space are hereby established
for any one (1) 24-hour parking period between five o'clock (5:00) A.M. on one
day to five o'clock (5:00) A.M. of the succeeding day as follows: (Ord. 97-3,
2-3-1997)
      1.   Daily Rate 1 : One dollar fifty cents ($1.50) per day. (Ord. 97-3,
2-3-1997; amd. Ord. 2007-59, 11-14-2007; Ord. 2008-49, 12-9-2008)
      2.   Monthly Rate: Thirty dollars ($30.00) per month. (Ord. 97-3, 2-3-
1997; amd. Ord. 2007-59, 11-14-2007; Ord. 2008-49, 12-9-2008; Ord. 2015-33, 7-
28-2015)
      3.   Exception: No fee for parking shall be required for the period
commencing nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. on Saturday morning through one minute
after twelve o'clock (12:01) A.M. Monday morning. (Ord. 97-3, 2-3-1997)
   D.   Violation:
      1.   A parking fee violation exists when:
         a.   There is insufficient money or tokens placed in the parking meter
slot for the designated parking space used for a vehicle during said twenty
four (24) hour period, or
         b.   There is no current monthly parking sticker plainly hanging from
the rearview mirror located above the dashboard. (Ord. 2002-44, 7-9-2002)
      2.   An unauthorized use violation occurs when:
         a.   The parking of any vehicle is such that any part of it occupies
more than one parking space or protrudes beyond the space in which its wheels
are located, or
         b.   The parking space is used by a vehicle in excess of two and one-
half (21/2) tons, or
         c.   The parking space is used by a disabled or nonoperating vehicle
at any time, or
         d.   The parking space is used continuously for five (5) successive
twenty four (24) hour periods and each twenty four (24) hour period is in fact
a parking fee violation. (Ord. 86-46, 12-1-1986)
   E.   Penalty:
      1.   In the event of a parking fee violation, i.e., the parking fee is
not paid on a daily basis or in the event the monthly fee is not paid or proof
of payment is not exhibited on the rearview mirror of the automobile by a
clearly valid sticker, then the registered owner of said vehicle is subject to
a fine of twenty five dollars ($25.00). If the twenty five dollar ($25.00) fine
is not paid within thirty (30) days after the Village notifies the registered
owner of the vehicle, then the fine shall be increased to seventy five dollars
($75.00) and the owner of the vehicle shall be notified of the increase. If the
increased amount is not paid within thirty (30) days after notification of the
increase, then the Police Department may issue a notice to appear so that the
violation will be presented and adjudicated pursuant to the Village's
administrative hearing procedures (chapter 7 of this title). (Ord. 2015-33, 7-
28-2015; amd. Ord. 2017-48, 10-24-2017)
      2.   In the event there is an unauthorized use violation of said parking
space, then the penalty shall not exceed the sum of five hundred dollars
($500.00) per day.
      3.   In the event any vehicle is in a parking space illegally after one
hundred twenty (120) hours, then said vehicle is subject to being towed from
the commuter parking lot and impounded and the owner shall be subject to
payment of the fee, the impoundment fee and a minimum fine to the Village of
not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and said vehicle shall not be
released until all charges aforesaid are paid. (Ord. 86-46, 12-1-1986)
 
Notes
1 1. These rates shall become effective on January 1, 2009.
CHAPTER 5
ABANDONED AND INOPERABLE VEHICLES
SECTION:
8-5-1: Definitions
8-5-2: Abandonment Prohibited
8-5-3: Notifying Police
8-5-4: Removal Authorized
8-5-5: Records Search For Owner
8-5-6: Reclaiming Vehicle
8-5-7: Sale Of Vehicle
8-5-8: Unidentified Owner
8-5-9: Records
8-5-10: Disposition Of Proceeds
8-5-11: Liability
8-5-12: Unenclosed Storage Of Unlicensed Vehicles Or Parts
8-5-13: Private Property
8-5-14: Repairing Junk Cars
8-5-15: Penalties
8-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
Terms used in this Chapter mean as follows:
   ABANDONED VEHICLE: Any motor vehicle or other vehicle in a state of
disrepair rendering the vehicle incapable of being driven in its condition; or
any motor vehicle or other vehicle that has not been moved or used for seven
(7) consecutive days or more and is apparently deserted.
   ANTIQUE VEHICLE: Any motor vehicle or other vehicle twenty five (25) years
of age or older.
   HIGHWAY: Any street, alley or public way within the Village. (1975 Code
§9.09)
8-5-2: ABANDONMENT PROHIBITED:
The abandonment of a motor vehicle or other vehicle or any part thereof on any
highway in this Village is unlawful and subject to penalties for violation of
this Code. The abandonment of a motor vehicle or other vehicle or any part
thereof on private or public property, other than a highway, in view of the
general public anywhere in the Village is unlawful except on property of the
owner or bailee of such abandoned vehicle. A motor vehicle or other vehicle or
any part thereof so abandoned on private property may be authorized for removal
by or upon the order of the Chief of Police, after a waiting period of seven
(7) days or more has expired.
8-5-3: NOTIFYING POLICE:
When an abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle or other vehicle
comes into the temporary possession or custody of a person in the Village, not
the owner of the vehicle, such person shall immediately notify the Police
Department when the vehicle is within the corporate limits of the Village. Upon
receipt of such notification, the Chief of Police shall authorize a towing
service to remove and take possession of the abandoned, lost, stolen or
unclaimed motor vehicle or other vehicle. The towing service will safely keep
the towed vehicle and its contents, maintain a record of the two until the
vehicle is claimed by the owner, or any other person legally entitled to
possession thereof, or until it is disposed of as provided in this Chapter.
8-5-4: REMOVAL AUTHORIZED:
When a motor vehicle or other vehicle is abandoned on a highway in the Village
ten (10) hours or more without notifying the police, its removal by a towing
service may be authorized by order of the Chief of Police. When an abandoned,
unattended wrecked, burned or partially dismantled motor vehicle or other
vehicle is creating a traffic hazard because of its position in relation to the
highway or its physical appearance is causing the impeding of traffic, its
immediate removal from the highway by a towing service may be authorized by
order of the Chief of Police. When a vehicle removed from either public or
private property is authorized by order of the Chief of Police, the owner of
the vehicle will be responsible for all towing costs.
8-5-5: RECORDS SEARCH FOR OWNER:
   A.   When the Police Department does not know the identity of the registered
owner or other legally entitled person, it will cause the motor vehicle
registration records of the State to be searched by a directed communication to
the Secretary of State for the purpose of obtaining the required ownership
information.
   B.   The Police Department shall cause the stolen motor vehicle files of the
Illinois State Police to be searched by a directed communication to the
Illinois State Police for stolen or wanted information on the vehicle. When the
Illinois State Police files are searched with negative results, the information
contained in the National Crime Information Center (NCIC) files will be
searched by the Illinois State Police. The information determined from these
record searches will be used by the Police Department in sending a notification
by certified mail to the owner or legally entitled person advising the vehicle
is held, requesting a disposition be made and setting forth public sale
information.
   C.   When the registered owner or other person legally entitled to the
possession of a motor vehicle or other vehicle cannot be identified from the
registration files of this State or from the registration files of a foreign
state, if applicable, the Police Department shall notify the Illinois State
Police for the purpose of identifying the vehicle's owner or other person
legally entitled to the possession of the vehicle. The information obtained by
the Illinois State Police will be immediately forwarded to the law enforcement
agency having custody of the vehicle for notification of owner.
8-5-6: RECLAIMING VEHICLE:
Any time before a motor vehicle is sold at public sale or disposed of as
provided herein, the owner or other person legally entitled to its possession
may reclaim the vehicle by presenting to the Police Department proof of
ownership or proof of the right to possession of the vehicle. No vehicle shall
be released to the owner or other person under this Section until all towing
and storage charges have been paid.
8-5-7: SALE OF VEHICLE:
   A.   Whenever an abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed vehicle, seven (7)
years of age or newer, remains unclaimed by the registered owner or other
person legally entitled to its possession for a period of thirty (30) days
after notice has been given as provided herein, the Police Department shall
cause it to be sold at public sale to the highest bidder. Notice of the time
and place of the sale shall be posted in a conspicuous place for at least ten
(10) days prior to the sale on the premises where the vehicle has been
impounded. At least ten (10) days prior to the sale, the Police Department
shall cause a notice of the time and place of the sale to be sent by certified
mail to the registered owner or other person known by the Police Department or
towing service to be legally entitled to the possession of the vehicle. Such
notice shall contain a complete description of the vehicle to be sold and what
steps must be taken by any legally entitled person to reclaim the vehicle.
   B.   In those instances where the certified notification specified herein
has been returned by the postal authorities to the Police Department due to the
addressee having moved, or being unknown at the address obtained from the
registration records of this State, the sending of a second certified notice
will not be required.
8-5-8: UNIDENTIFIED OWNER:
   A.   When the identity of the registered owner or other person legally
entitled to the possession of an abandoned, lost or unclaimed vehicle of seven
(7) years of age or newer cannot be determined by any means provided for in
this Chapter, the vehicle may be sold as provided herein or disposed of in the
manner authorized by this Chapter without notice to the registered owner or
other person legally entitled to the possession of the vehicle.
   B.   When an abandoned vehicle of more than seven (7) years of age is
impounded as specified by this Chapter, it will be kept in custody for a
minimum of ten (10) days for the purpose of determining ownership, the contact
of the registered owner by the U.S. mail, public service or in person for a
determination of disposition, and an examination of the Illinois State Police
stolen motor vehicle files for theft and wanted information. At the expiration
of the ten (10) day period, without the benefit of disposition information
being received from the registered owner, the Chief of Police shall authorize
the disposal of the vehicle as junk only.
   C.   A motor vehicle or other vehicle classified as an antique vehicle is
excluded from this Section.
8-5-9: RECORDS:
When a motor vehicle or other vehicle in the custody of the Police Department
is reclaimed by the registered owner or other legally entitled person, or when
the vehicle is sold at public sale or otherwise disposed of as provided in this
Chapter, a record of the transaction will be maintained by the Police
Department for a period of one year from the date of the sale or disposal.
8-5-10: DISPOSITION OF PROCEEDS:
When a vehicle located within the Village is authorized to be towed away by the
Chief of Police and disposed of as set forth in this Chapter, the proceeds of
the public sale or disposition after the deduction of towing, storage and
processing charges shall be deposited in the Village Treasury. (1975 Code
§9.09)
8-5-11: LIABILITY:
Any police officer, towing service owner, operator or employee shall not be
held to answer or be liable for damages in any action brought by the registered
owner, former registered owner or his legal representative, or any other person
legally entitled to the possession of a motor vehicle or other vehicle when the
vehicle was processed and sold or disposed of as provided by this Chapter.
(Ord. 87-25, 8-3-87)
8-5-12: UNENCLOSED STORAGE OF UNLICENSED VEHICLES OR PARTS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, deposit or cause to be
kept or deposited on any land located within the corporate limits of the
Village, any vehicles of the type or types which would be required under the
applicable statutes of the State to be registered for operation on any public
highway; or any part or parts intended for use in any such vehicle. It shall be
unlawful for any owner of any such land to suffer or permit such land to be
used for the storage of any such vehicle or part or parts therefor, unless such
vehicles or parts shall be:
      1.   Duly registered for operation on public highways in the State, as
required by applicable statutes and by any administrative rule, regulation or
determination issued pursuant hereto.
      2.   Wholly enclosed within a building or buildings, or such vehicle or
part or parts thereof shall be located within a junkyard maintained and
operated in accordance with the applicable ordinances of the Village.
      3.   Removed from such land or brought into compliance with the
provisions of paragraphs 1 and 2 of this subsection within thirty (30) days
after the Village gives written notice of the violation of the provisions of
this Section by registered or certified mail addressed to the last
ascertainable address of the owner of such land.
   B.   Any person who violates any provision of this Section shall be subject
to a fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00) for each such violation. Each day such violation
shall continue more than thirty (30) days after the date of a written notice
given, pursuant to paragraph A3, shall constitute a separate offense hereunder.
(Ord. 78-15, 6-19-78)
8-5-13: PRIVATE PROPERTY:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep an inoperable motor vehicle
or any parts thereof on any private property located within the Village and in
view of the general public.
   B.   Inoperable motor vehicles means any motor vehicle from which, for a
period of at least seven (7) days, the engine, wheels or other parts have been
removed, or on which the engine, wheels or other parts have been altered,
damaged or otherwise so treated or nonequipped that the vehicle is incapable of
being driven under its own power upon any road or highway but it shall not
include a motor vehicle which has been rendered temporarily incapable of being
driven under its own motor power in order to perform ordinary service or repair
operations, or to any motor vehicle kept within a building, to operable
historic vehicles over twenty five (25) years of age registered with the State
as an antique vehicle, or to a motor vehicle on the premises of a place engaged
in the wrecking or junking of motor vehicles maintained and operated in
accordance with the applicable ordinances of the Village.
   C.   The Village shall prior to the commencement of any prosecution under
this Section, and/or removal of said inoperable motor vehicle or parts thereof,
give written notice of the violation of the provisions of this Chapter either
by personally serving said notice upon the owner of the property on which the
vehicle is located or by sending a copy of said notice by certified mail to the
owner of said property. Said notice shall provide that unless said person
disposes of the inoperable motor vehicle or parts thereof within seven (7)
days, the Village will commence prosecution for the violation and/or have said
vehicle or parts thereof removed from the property.
   D.   In the event said inoperable motor vehicle does not have current
Illinois State license plates and/or a current Fox Lake Village sticker, it
shall constitute a separate violation and offense. (Ord. 88-5, 1988)
8-5-14: REPAIRING JUNK CARS:
It shall be unlawful to engage in remodeling or repairing of so- called junk
cars on public streets, parkways or in any residential district. (1975 Code §
9.12)
8-5-15: PENALTIES:
Unless otherwise provided, any person who violates any provision of this
chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day that
the violation continues shall be considered a separate offense subject to the
penalties prescribed. (Ord. 83-19, 9-19-1983; amd. Ord. 2017-48, 10-24-2017)
